Engine¶

Wrappers¶

This module defines the AbstractEngine and Engine classes. AbstractEngine is just a template used for type annotations. Engine is just a wrapper/addaptor for an Evaluator and Generator.

class pyneg.engine.engine.AbstractEngine[source]¶

Bases: object

AbstractEngine class is mostly used for type annotations and provides a template for implementing new engines.

__init__()[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

add_utilities(new_utils: Dict[str, float]) → bool[source]¶

Add utilities to the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the evaluator doesn’t reason about this, it should always return true.

Parameters

new_utils (AtomicDict) – an atomic dictionary of the utilities to add

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

should return true if there are still potentially offers possible.

Return type

bool

set_utilities(new_utils: Dict[str, float]) → bool[source]¶

sets the utilities in the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the evaluator doesn’t reason about this, it should always return true. similar to add-utilities but overwrites all previous utilities.

Parameters

new_utils (AtomicDict) – an atomic dictionary of the utilities to add

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

should return true if there are still potentially offers possible.

Return type

bool

add_constraint(constraint: pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint) → bool[source]¶

Add the given constraint to the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the agent doesn’t reason about constrints, this should be a no-op and always return true.

Parameters

constraint (AtomicConstraint) – The constraint to add

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

Whether there are still potential acceptable solutions

Return type

bool

add_constraints(new_constraints: Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint]) → bool[source]¶

Add multiple constraints to the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the agent doesn’t reason about constrints, this should be a no-op and always return true.

Parameters

accepts(offer: pyneg.comms.offer.Offer) → bool[source]¶

Determines whether the agent finds an offer acceptable. Usually this is decided by determining whether the utility of the offer is higher than the reservation value.

Parameters

offer (Offer) – The offer to consider

Raises

NotImplementedError – [description]

Returns

True if the offer is acceptable according to the known criteria.

Return type

bool

class pyneg.engine.engine.Engine(generator: pyneg.engine.generator.Generator, evaluator: pyneg.engine.evaluator.Evaluator)[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.engine.AbstractEngine

This class is where all of the reasoning about offers happens. Mostly it’s a wrapper for the Generator and Evaluator class

Evaluators¶

Constrained Linear Evaluator¶

Defines the ConstrainedLinearEvaluator class, the contraint aware version of LinearEvaluator

class pyneg.engine.constrained_linear_evaluator.ConstrainedLinearEvaluator(utilities: Dict[str, float], issue_weights: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, constr_value: float, initial_constraints: Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint])[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.linear_evaluator.LinearEvaluator

This class is the contraint aware version of LinearEvaluator. It works the same except that for any offer that violates one of the known constraints it returns a utility of constr_value.

__init__(utilities: Dict[str, float], issue_weights: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, constr_value: float, initial_constraints: Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint])[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

add_constraint(constraint: pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint) → bool[source]¶

Add the given constraint to the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the agent doesn’t reason about constrints, this should be a no-op and always return true.

Parameters

constraint (AtomicConstraint) – The constraint to add

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

Whether there are still potential acceptable solutions

Return type

bool

add_constraints(new_constraints: Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint]) → bool[source]¶

Add multiple constraints to the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the agent doesn’t reason about constrints, this should be a no-op and always return true.

Parameters

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Return type

calc_assignment_util(issue: str, value: str) → float[source]¶

calculates the utility gained from a perticular signed assignment asignements with unknown utilities are assigned 0 utility

>>> print(self.utilities)
{"boolean_False": -10, "boolean_True":10, "integer_3": 100}
>>> self.calc_assignment_util("boolean","False")
-10
>>> self.calc_assignment_util("unknown","unknown")
0
Parameters

  • issue (str) – the issue the assignment is associated with

  • value (str) – the value of the potential assignement

Returns

the utility of the experiement

Return type

float

calc_offer_utility(offer: pyneg.comms.offer.Offer) → float[source]¶

Calculates the utility of a full offer. In this implementation this is simply the dot product of the utility of all the asignements with their associated issue weights

Parameters

offer (Offer) – The offer to calculate the utility of

Returns

the utility the given offer is worth

Return type

float

calc_strat_utility(strat: pyneg.engine.strategy.Strategy) → float[source]¶

Generalisation of an offer but works similarly. calculates the expceted utility under the strategy distribution. see Strategy for more information.

Parameters

strat (Strategy) – the strategy to calculate the utility of

Returns

expected utility under the given strategy with current knowledge base

Return type

float

satisfies_all_constraints(to_check: Union[pyneg.comms.offer.Offer, pyneg.engine.strategy.Strategy]) → bool[source]¶

Checks whether the given offer or strategy satisfies all known constraints.

Parameters

to_check (Union[Offer, Strategy]) – The offer or strategy to check

Raises

TypeError – if an object of unknown type is passed.

Returns

True iff the given offer or strategy satisfies all known constraints.

Return type

bool

pyneg.engine.constrained_problog_evaluator module¶

Defines the ConstrainedProblogEvaluator class, the contraint aware version of ProblogEvaluator see that entry for more information.

class pyneg.engine.constrained_problog_evaluator.ConstrainedProblogEvaluator(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, knowledge_base: List[str], constr_value: float, initial_constraints: Optional[Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint]])[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.problog_evaluator.ProblogEvaluator

This class is equal to the ProblogEvaluator class but with additional logic to handle constraints. See ProblogEvaluator for more information on how ProbLog is used.

__init__(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, knowledge_base: List[str], constr_value: float, initial_constraints: Optional[Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint]])[source]¶

calc_strat_utility(strat: pyneg.engine.strategy.Strategy) → float[source]¶

Calculate the expected utility of a strategy, meaning the expected utility of an offer that is sampled from this strattegy under the current knowledge base.

Parameters

Returns

add_constraint(constraint: pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint) → bool[source]¶

Add the given constraint to the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the agent doesn’t reason about constrints, this should be a no-op and always return true.

sets the utilities in the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the evaluator doesn’t reason about this, it should always return true. similar to add-utilities but overwrites all previous utilities.

should return true if there are still potentially offers possible.

calc_assignment_util(issue: str, value: str) → float[source]¶

Calculates the utility of a single issue value assignement. Only possible for linear additive utility functions.

Parameters

  • issue (str) – the issue the assignements is refering too

  • value (str) – the potential value of the assignement

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

The increase in utility that the assignement would cause

Return type

float

pyneg.engine.evaluator module¶

Nothing but an abstract class. Sometimes used for type annotations and as a template for implementing your own. Evaluators are what agent engines use to evaluate offers. All logic relating to reasoning and evaluating potential offers should be located here.

class pyneg.engine.evaluator.Evaluator[source]¶

Bases: object

Nothing but an abstract class. Sometimes used for type annotations and as a template for implementing your own. Evaluators are what agent engines use to evaluate offers. All logic relating to reasoning and evaluating potential offers should be located here.

__init__()[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

pyneg.engine.linear_evaluator module¶

A simple evaluator that calculates the utility of an offer assuming Linear additivity

class pyneg.engine.linear_evaluator.LinearEvaluator(utilities: Dict[str, float], issue_weights: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float)[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.evaluator.Evaluator

Evaluates offers using linear additive calculations. (see Linear additivity) Utilities should be a utility function represented as an AtomicDict, issue weights should be a distribution over the issues and non_agreement_cost should be the cost of unsuccessfully terminating the negotiation.

__init__(utilities: Dict[str, float], issue_weights: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float)[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

should return true if there are still potentially offers possible.

Return type

bool

pyneg.engine.problog_evaluator module¶

This module defines the ProblogEvaluator class.

class pyneg.engine.problog_evaluator.ProblogEvaluator(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, knowledge_base: List[str])[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.evaluator.Evaluator

This evaluator uses ProbLog to calculate the utility of offers. That means that it can deal with probabalistic as well as deterministic knowledge bases and use them correctly to infer consequences. This is however, much slower than the other classes. The knowledge base should be represented as valid ProbLog statements see https://dtai.cs.kuleuven.be/problog/ for more information.

__init__(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, knowledge_base: List[str])[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

add_utilities(new_utils: Dict[str, float]) → bool[source]¶

Add utilities to the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the evaluator doesn’t reason about this, it should always return true.

Parameters

new_utils (AtomicDict) – an atomic dictionary of the utilities to add

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

should return true if there are still potentially offers possible.

Return type

bool

calc_probabilities_of_utilities(offer: pyneg.comms.offer.Offer) → Dict[str, float][source]¶

Uses ProbLog and the known knowledge_base to calculate the probability of each of the known utilities to occur so we can use it to calculate the expected utility of an offer.

Parameters

offer (Offer) – The offer you want to calculate the utility of

Returns

A dictionary with known utilities as keys and the probability they will be fufilled as values.

Return type

Dict[str, float]

compile_problog_model(offer: pyneg.comms.offer.Offer) → str[source]¶

Compile the offer, knowledge base and known utilities into a string representing a valid ProbLog model.

Parameters

offer (Offer) – The offer that needs to be incoprated into the model.

Returns

A string representation of the model including knowledge base and utilities

Return type

str

add_constraints(new_constraints: Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint]) → bool[source]¶

pyneg.engine.constrained_dtp_generator module¶

This module defines ConstrainedDTPGenerator which is the constraint aware version of DTPGenerator

class pyneg.engine.constrained_dtp_generator.ConstrainedDTPGenerator(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, acceptance_threshold: float, kb: List[str], constr_value: float, initial_constraints: Optional[Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint]], auto_constraints=True)[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.dtp_generator.DTPGenerator

This class defines the constraint aware version of the DTPGenerator. This means that it also uses DTProbLog to generate optimal offers but adds additional logic to deal with constraints. For more information see DTPGenerator

__init__(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, acceptance_threshold: float, kb: List[str], constr_value: float, initial_constraints: Optional[Set[pyneg.comms.atomic_constraint.AtomicConstraint]], auto_constraints=True)[source]¶

accepts(offer: pyneg.comms.offer.Offer) → bool[source]¶

Determines whether the given offer is acceptable under the current knowledge base. This means calculating it’s utility and checking that it is above the acceptablity threshold. In addition, it has to satisfy all known constraints.

generate_offer() → pyneg.comms.offer.Offer[source]¶

Generates offer in breath first manner. Most of the work is done in init_generator(), expand_assignement() and _offer_from_index_dict() this function just takes the next offer from the priorityQueue and converts it into an offer.

Raises

StopIteration – Raised when no acceptable offers can be found. in this case this is the case if we find offers that have utility below acceptance threshold because we use BFS.

Returns

The next best offer with the current knowledge base.

Return type

Offer

generate_offer() → pyneg.comms.offer.Offer[source]¶

Generate an offer by sampling from the current strategy until the maximum amount of tries are reached or the maximum number of offers are generated. (this is to insure that it terminates even in impossible situations.)

pyneg.engine.dtp_generator module¶

This module devines the DTPGenerator class, which uses DTProbLog to generate optimal offers in settings that include probabalistic knowledge bases.

class pyneg.engine.dtp_generator.DTPGenerator(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, acceptability_threshold: float, knowledge_base: List[str])[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.generator.Generator

This generator class uses DTProbLog to generate optimal offers. Since it uses DTProbLog it can reason about offers using utilities, both atomic and compound and also using arbitrary knowledge bases. It does mean that it is very slow and prone to memory leaks due to the python implementation of DTProbLog

__init__(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], non_agreement_cost: float, acceptability_threshold: float, knowledge_base: List[str])[source]¶

str

_extend_partial_offer(partial_offer: Dict[str, float]) → Set[pyneg.comms.offer.Offer][source]¶

When some decision variables have no impact on the final utility DTProbLog will generate partial answers. This function will expand those final offers into all of their full options so we can propose them. e.g.

>>> gen = DTPGenerator(
    neg_space = {"boolean":["True","False"], "dummy":["1","2"]},
    utilities = {"boolean_True":100},
    non_agreement_cost = -100,
    acceptability_threshold = 10,
    knowledge_base = []
)
>>> program = PrologString(gen._compile_dtproblog_model())
>>> query_output, score, _ = dtproblog(program)
>>> query_output
{boolean_True: 1}
>>> cleaned_query_output = gen.clean_query_output(query_output)
>>> gen._extend_partial_offer(cleaned_query_output)
{[boolean->True, dummy->1], [boolean->True, dummy->2]}
Parameters

partial_offer ([type]) –

Raises

valueerror – [description]

Returns

[description]

Return type

Set[Offer]

_clean_query_output(query_output: Dict[Term, float]) → Dict[str, float][source]¶

sometimes dtproblog can return things such as “choice(0,0,boolean_true)” under certain circumstances so we need to filter these. This function also casts the keys from problog.logic.Term to str so we can manipulate them.

Parameters

query_output (Dict[problog.logic.Term, float]) – the raw output dictionary from DTProbLog

Returns

A dictionary containing the cleaned assignements of the optimal offer

Return type

Dict[str, float]

pyneg.engine.enum_generator module¶

A very simple deterministic negotiation agent which just enumerates offers in order of preference. Uses breath first search. see EnumGenerator for more information.

class pyneg.engine.enum_generator.EnumGenerator(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], evaluator: pyneg.engine.evaluator.Evaluator, acceptability_threshold: float)[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.generator.Generator

A simple deterministic offer generator that lists offers in order of preference. This implemantation only works for linear additive spaces and utilty functions. It uses breath first search to explore the negotiation space. Raises StopIteration exception when it cannot find any new acceptable offers.

__init__(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], evaluator: pyneg.engine.evaluator.Evaluator, acceptability_threshold: float) → None[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

init_generator() → None[source]¶

Setup for the breath first search. This is done by indexing the negotiation space internally by utility e.g. >>> neg_space = {“boolean”:[“True”, “False”]} the utility function {“boolean_True”:10,”boolean_False”:100} would be converted to {“boolean”: [“False”,”True”]}

accepts(offer: pyneg.comms.offer.Offer) → bool[source]¶

Determine whether the offer is acceptble according to the known criteria.

Parameters

offer (Offer) – The offer to be checked

Returns

True iff the offer is acceptable according to the criteria.

Return type

bool

_expand_assignment(sorted_offer_indices: Dict[str, int]) → None[source]¶

Takes a typle of offer indices and generates new valid offer indices from them, to be used in offer generation, and puts them on the fronteir. For example assume there are three issues with each three values, and each assignement has utility equal to the values. i.e.

>>> neg_space = {"A":[1,2,3],"B":[4,5,6],"C":[7,8,9]}

and [A->1,B->4,C->7] would have utility 1+4+7 = 12 then

>>> expand_assignment((2,1,1))

would generate {(2,1,2),(2,2,2),(0,2,2)} and put them in the fronteir. Note that the indices (i.e. the 2,1,1) don’t correspond to the indices in the negotiation space but to the indices of the internal list of values sorted by utility. See init_generator() for more info.

Parameters

sorted_offer_indices (Tuple[int]) – a tuple of indices corresponding to entries in the internal list refering to vaues

generate_offer() → pyneg.comms.offer.Offer[source]¶

Generates offer in breath first manner. Most of the work is done in init_generator(), expand_assignement() and _offer_from_index_dict() this function just takes the next offer from the priorityQueue and converts it into an offer.

Raises

StopIteration – Raised when no acceptable offers can be found. in this case this is the case if we find offers that have utility below acceptance threshold because we use BFS.

Returns

The next best offer with the current knowledge base.

Return type

Offer

_offer_from_index_dict(index_dict: Dict[str, int]) → pyneg.comms.offer.Offer[source]¶

converts indicies corresponding to the internal list of values into actuall offers. e.g. assume we have

>>> neg_space = {"A":["first","second","third"],"B":["fourth","fifth","sixth"]
,"C":["seventh","eighth","ninth"]}
and each assignement has utility equal to the values. i.e.
[A->"first",B->"forth",C->"seventh"] would have utility 1+4+7 = 12 then 
we would have 

>>> _offer_from_index_dict({"A":2,"C":0,"B":1}).get_sparse_str_repr()
[A->"first",B->"fifth", C->"ninth"]
Parameters

index_dict (Dict[str, int]) – The dictionarry mapping issues to the corresponding index in the internal list

Returns

An offer with the mapping corresponding to the indices passed in

Return type

Offer

pyneg.engine.generator module¶

Generator Nothing but an abstract class. Sometimes used for type annotations and as a template for implementing your own. Generators are what agent engines use to generate offers. All logic relating to reasoning and finding potential offers should be located here.

class pyneg.engine.generator.Generator[source]¶

Bases: object

Nothing but an abstract class. Sometimes used for type annotations and as a template for implementing your own. Generators are what agent engines use to generate offers. All logic relating to reasoning and finding potential offers should be located here.

  • utilities: a utility mapping.

  • knowledge_base: a knowledge base. only supported if the generator uses ProbLog

  • acceptability_threshold: minimum utility needed for the agent to accept an offer

__init__()[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

generate_offer() → pyneg.comms.offer.Offer[source]¶

Generates the next offer the agent should propose.

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

The offer the agent should propose

Return type

Offer

set_utilities(new_utils: Dict[str, float]) → bool[source]¶

sets the utilities in the knowledge base. Returns true if there are still potential acceptable solutions. If the evaluator doesn’t reason about this, it should always return true. similar to add-utilities but overwrites all previous utilities.

Parameters

new_utils (AtomicDict) – an atomic dictionary of the utilities to add

Raises

NotImplementedError –

Returns

should return true if there are still potentially offers possible.

Return type

bool

pyneg.engine.random_generator module¶

Defines the RandomGenerator class.

class pyneg.engine.random_generator.RandomGenerator(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], evaluator: pyneg.engine.evaluator.Evaluator, non_agreement_cost: float, knowledge_base: List[str], acceptability_threshold: float, max_rounds: int, max_generation_tries: int = 1000)[source]¶

Bases: pyneg.engine.generator.Generator

This generator generates random offers without any reasoning. By default it uses uniform distriutions across all issues and values.

Raises

StopIteration – when maximum number of samples for one offer or maximum total number offers generated is exceded

__init__(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]], utilities: Dict[str, float], evaluator: pyneg.engine.evaluator.Evaluator, non_agreement_cost: float, knowledge_base: List[str], acceptability_threshold: float, max_rounds: int, max_generation_tries: int = 1000)[source]¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

init_uniform_strategy(neg_space: Dict[str, List[str]]) → None[source]¶

Initialises a uniform distribution across all possible values for every issue.

Parameters

neg_space (NegSpace) – The negotiation space that the strategy will be based on.

generate_offer() → pyneg.comms.offer.Offer[source]¶

Generate an offer by sampling from the current strategy until the maximum amount of tries are reached or the maximum number of offers are generated. (this is to insure that it terminates even in impossible situations.)

Raises

  • StopIteration – [description]

  • StopIteration – [description]

Returns

[description]

Return type

Offer

pyneg.engine.strategy module¶

This module defines the strategy that probabalistic generators can use. See Strategy for more information.

class pyneg.engine.strategy.Strategy(values_by_issue: Union[Dict[str, Dict[str, float]], Dict[str, float]], indent_level: int = 1, verbose=<Verbosity.none: 0>)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class that probabalistic generators can use to generate offers by sampling. A stagy consists of a distribution for every issue over it’s possible values.

Raises

  • ValueError – raised if input doesn’t have the right structure e.g. if some of the vectors arent a distribution

  • KeyError – [description]

Returns

[description]

Return type

[type]

normalise_issue(issue: str) → None[source]¶

Normalise distribution of the given issue.

Parameters

issue (str) – the issue who’s distribution you want to normalise

get_problog_dists() → str[source]¶

Formats the offer as a distribution over the atomic issue value pairs. This is just so ProbLog agents can reason about them.

>>> Offer(atomic).get_problog_dists()
0.0::First_A;1.0::First_B.
1.0::Second_C;0.0::Second_D.
Returns

A string expressing the offer in valid ProbLog as a distribution over the atomic issue value pairs.

Return type

str
